Well, good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to
the National Gallery and welcome to the first

25.text:
talk in a series around our new exhibition,
Making Colour.

31.text: My name's Ashok Roy. I'm the Gallery's Director of Collections. And this is Dr Caroline Campbell.

39.text: Caroline and I have worked together over a number of years to put on the Making Colour exhibition and we

45.text:
thought it would be interesting to have a
conversation about some of the aspects of

52.text:
mounting this exhibition; some of the things
that we thought about and even some of the

57.text:
things that we haven't been able to include.
Obviously, although the Sainsbury Wing galleries

63.text:
are fairly large we are limited in scope in
the things that we can show. And you might

70.text:
have noticed that although we've tried to
cover all the, sort of, principal colours

74.text:
of the spectrum in the exhibition those
of you that have seen the exhibition will

78.text:
realise that we haven't, for example,
been able to say anything about the colour

84.text:
black or black pigments or indeed the colour
white, if you call white a colour, and white

89.text:
pigments.
And we will say a little bit about those subjects

93.text:
during the course of this afternoon. But I'm
going to begin just to tell you a little bit

98.text:
about the origins of this exhibition. Not
everyone knows that the National Gallery has

106.text:
at the back of the building a scientific laboratory
on the top floor. And you can see that there,

113.text:
it faces onto Orange Street right at the back
of the Gallery. And that has been there since

119.text:
1975 when the National Gallery Northern Extension
was built. In fact, it's an older institution

128.text:
of the Gallery than 1975 and it moved from
another part of the building.

134.text:
The function of the Gallery's scientific laboratory
really is to study the National Gallery collection

140.text:
and the primary purpose of that work is to
understand paintings better for their conservation needs.

148.text:
Now, as a result of analysing paintings
we, of course, have over the years begun to

157.text:
gather a lot of information about the materials
used by painters traditionally, or the painters

163.text:
of, the creators of the National Gallery pictures.
And so, we've been gathering, or trying, as

169.text:
it were, to write the story of the technique
of European painting.

174.text:
And one aspect of that story is the history
of the use of colouring materials, that is

181.text:
pigments, in paintings in European works of
art. The business of actually analysing paintings

188.text:
is quite a scientific and technological affair
and we have in the laboratory, these are some

194.text:
of my colleagues in the scientific department,
working with scientific instruments which

199.text:
are, have been chosen as means of understanding
the material nature of tiny samples of paint

207.text:
taken from pictures in the collection when
they're undergoing conservation treatment.

211.text:
And these samples are taken in order to understand
the constitution of paint, including the pigments

217.text:
used by painters. So it's a very scientific
and technological matter. Now, we have a bit

225.text:
of a tradition actually at the National Gallery
of explaining to our various publics how pictures

233.text:
are made. And, in fact, going back some while
we had an exhibition called Art in the Making

238.text:
which concentrated on Rembrandt's painting
technique. And this is going back to the late

244.text:
1980s. And you see here two late, great portraits
by Rembrandt and a didactic panel from that

253.text:
exhibition which tried to explain how Rembrandt
had created these works of art.

259.text:
And the techniques that we used to elucidate
painting technique are the same techniques

265.text:
that we've used in Making Colour to tell our
visitors what kind of painting materials,

272.text:
particularly pigments, were involved. And
we did the same a little while later for impressionist

278.text:
painting in a second Art in the Making show.
We also try to make available to the public

288.text:
information on the techniques of painting
in this collection through a regular journal

293.text:
which is published in conventional form. It's
called the National Gallery Technical Bulletin.

298.text:
It appears every year.
And we make that journal available with no

303.text:
charge on the Gallery's website now so you
can explore its content going right back to

309.text:
the foundations of the Technical Bulletin
in 1977. So it is a very good way of understanding

317.text:
the techniques of painting in pictures in
the collection here. Now, I mentioned the

327.text:
techniques that we use to understand the way
paintings are made. One of the classic means

332.text:
is to make what are called paint cross-sections.
And you see here a paint cross-section from

340.text:
a picture by Monet. It's actually a 20th Century
picture.

345.text:
This is Irises from about, between 1914 and
1917. And this is a tiny really miniscule

353.text:
fragment of paint which is mounted for examination
under the microscope. And I show it to you

357.text:
because not only is it very revealing as to
Monet's materials, it's also, I think, a very

365.text:
attractive image in its own right. And by
looking at a sample such as this we can tell

371.text:
the pigments that Monet used to create that
passage of paint. And you can see he's one

378.text:
for mixing a lot of pigment together. In the
under-layer which is from a yellowish-green

383.text:
area you can see a deep green pigment, it's
a pigment called viridian, a mauve pigment

389.text:
called cobalt violet and a number of other
materials.

392.text:
And we're able, if we're not able to identify
these pigments just from their optical properties,

400.text:
we're able to tell what they are by analysing
samples such as that. I'm now going to hand

407.text:
over to Caroline. Quite a shock to see this
image suddenly appearing.

411.text:
No, Ashok and I, as Ashok said, we thought
it would be good to talk you through some

417.text:
parts of the exhibition and then also to address
the question of why we have addressed certain

422.text:
subjects and why we haven't. And as you'll
know, those of you who've seen the exhibition,

426.text:
and those of you who haven't, I hope you enjoy
it when you do, we start with a room which

432.text:
is really trying to do a very great deal in
a very small amount of space. And it's a room

438.text:
that we discussed, I think, very, very much
in the two years that we worked together on

442.text:
the exhibition.
I should say that the exhibition, it was originally

446.text:
the idea of our Director, Nicholas Penney,
who suggested to Ashok that this would be

450.text:
a wonderful subject for a show. And Ashok
and I have worked on it together since I joined

456.text:
the Gallery about a year after the discussions
for the exhibition started. And we wanted

461.text:
to really demonstrate, I think, that colour
doesn't happen in a vacuum in Western European

467.text:
paintings, that there's a long context for
the use of colour. Of course, it's one of

473.text:
the most critical things that any maker, in
particular a painter, thinks about.

478.text:
But most of that story had to go from the
exhibition because it was too complex. So

483.text:
we're trying to represent, or at least draw
attention to the fact that Western European

488.text:
doesn't happen in a vacuum and there's a long
tradition of the use of colour in antiquity

493.text:
by the display of this very, very compelling
portrait from a Roman mummy; from a mummy

501.text:
of the Antonine period found in Egypt in Hawara
in the very early 20th Century. An object

508.text:
dating from the mid-first century AD where
the sense of engagement with us, or indeed

515.text:
whoever the beholder of this picture might
have been it would have been on the front

519.text:
of a mummy  is absolutely extraordinary.
The colours are quite different, aren't they,

524.text:
we think, to those used in European painting.
That's right and there's a much more limited

530.text:
range, I think, at this period. Did you mention
that this is a wax�?

534.text:
I didn't mention that. You should.
Well, it's very interesting because this mummy

541.text:
portrait, unlike the pictures in the National
Gallery collection, is painted in a medium

546.text:
of melted wax so it's beeswax which is the
actual binder for the pigment. It's a very

553.text:
durable technique but it's not very flexible.
It's a rather difficult thing to pull off

559.text:
successfully. And one thing that I think is
characteristic of wax painting is that it's

564.text:
quite difficult as with tempera painting to
get a very subtle modelling of light and shade.

570.text:
So although this is a very wonderful image,
it doesn't have the sort of quality of light

575.text:
and shade that an oil painting as a portrait
would have.

578.text:
No, absolutely not and that's something, of
course, which painters have developed hugely

582.text:
in the 750 years or so that are represented
in our collection. So really in this first

589.text:
part of the exhibition we wanted to introduce
the concept, something which we all know from

594.text:
our days in primary school, but some of us
may have forgotten, the idea that colour theory

599.text:
is really centred around, or the conception
of colour, how we conceive, perceive and think

604.text:
about colour, and its expression in the physical
form of a painting, in the idea of the primaries.

610.text:
And by this juxtaposition which we make in
the show between Crivelli's Saints Peter and

615.text:
St Paul of the 1470s and Annibale Carracci's
Domine Quo Vadis of the very early 17th Century,

622.text:
you'll see that in both these pictures, painters
are using the idea of the primary colours

628.text:
of red and yellow and blue almost instinctively
and before there are theories of colour it's

634.text:
something that painters clearly thought about
a great deal. Wouldn't you agree, Ashok?

639.text:
I think that's absolutely right. I think there
is an instinctive response to the primary

644.text:
colours which is a human phenomenon and it
obviously goes back to before the beginnings

650.text:
of representational art. So I think we've,
sort of, come in at a point in the 15th Century

657.text:
but, of course, I think these kinds of responses
to colour are much older than that.

662.text:
Absolutely, I mean, they're as old as the
objects themselves, or indeed the writing

667.text:
themselves, I mean, from antiquity onwards
and clearly that's just too big a subject

671.text:
to really address in the space of the show.
But we also wanted to allude to the fact that,

677.text:
of course, there are many theories of colour
which very much do impact on Western painters

683.text:
from the 17th Century onwards. And, of course,
Newton's findings about light were very important

690.text:
also to colour in pictorial form as well.
And we're showing several colour wheels in

695.text:
the exhibition, some on the wall and one by
Moses Harris, the entomologist, which you

701.text:
see on the slide here, in a book. It's in
a particularly beautiful book that belonged

706.text:
to the painter William Etty and was bequeathed
by him to the Royal Academy in the 1840s.

711.text:
Can I just say a thing about the Moses Harris?
At the centre you see three coloured triangles

720.text:
of representing the three primary colours
and where they overlap they're represented

725.text:
as making the colour black, or absence of
colour. And this is quite a new thought, that

731.text:
the primary colours, when combined as pigment
or as paint, make a very dark colour. If you

737.text:
actually work with red, blue and yellow, mix
them together you get a, sort of, rather,

741.text:
a sort of dark sludgy brown, that's true.
But in the theoretical sense, the product

747.text:
is black. So, and, that's very acute of Moses
Harris to understand.

751.text:
It is extremely acute of Moses Harris. And
isn't it true that he was somebody who looked

755.text:
at butterflies' wings and then tried to expand
from that?

760.text:
That's right, although what he didn't know
about butterflies' wings, the actual colour

765.text:
in the insect wing doesn't arrive from pigment
in general but it arrives from the actual

771.text:
cellular structure of the wing itself and
the way that the cells interact with light.

777.text:
And there's no actual pigment there in most
cases.

780.text:
It's amazing. But yet he used that to produce
a theory of colour which actually works in

787.text:
a pictorial sense.
And didn't you tell me he is a printer as

790.text:
well? That' s [overtalking].
That's right. That's right. I found that fascinating

793.text:
when I went to look at the object in the Royal
Academy Library about a year-and-a-half ago

797.text:
that he's a printer and so he's very, very,
very interested - it's very interesting to

802.text:
have these, you know, one of the art and
the science combining and, of course, that's

807.text:
something which we think about here at the
Gallery but we suspect that some of our audience

811.text:
don't, we don't think about the crossover
of these forms as much as perhaps we should.

816.text:
And we hope the exhibition enables people
to do that.

819.text:
One, I just wanted to mention very briefly
a subject that Ashok has worked on almost

824.text:
more than anybody, and that's the relationship
between new 19th Century theories of colour,

830.text:
particularly this theory by Michel Chevreul
who was the director of the Gobelin tapestry

836.text:
workshop in Paris and who produced this fascinating
and very, very much used by painters theory

843.text:
of colour. That if you put opposing colours,
colours on his colour wheel. I'll see if

849.text:
I can get this to work  that are opposite
each other, such as blue and orange here,

855.text:
the colours stand out more strongly and really
a very classic example of that is Renoir's

862.text:
painting here where you can see the orange-yellow
of the skiff against the blue of the water

868.text:
that the two women are boating in.
And there is such an interesting conjunction

874.text:
between theories and paintings in the late
19th Century that's almost unsurpassed, isn't

878.text:
it?
I think that's right. This particular colour

883.text:
theory or colour effect was one that appealed
tremendously to the Impressionists but they

888.text:
couldn't really have exploited it, I don't
think, without some of the new inventions

893.text:
on the artist's palette in the 19th Century.
And I think the Renoir's a very good example

897.text:
of that because that bright orange colour
is actually a new 19th Century pigment called

903.text:
chrome orange. And although you can get a
colour which approaches it by mixing red and

910.text:
yellow, you don't quite get the same colour
intensity as when the pigment has that intrinsic

916.text:
colour.
So the availability of chrome orange and

921.text:
here Renoir set it against another 19th Century
invention called cobalt blue  exploits

927.text:
this complementary contrast effect at particularly
good advantage I think.

931.text:
And as Ashok mentioned, the theory and practice
are very strongly connected and artists' materials;

938.text:
I mean, Ashok was just saying that without
these new materials the Impressionists couldn't

942.text:
have made these great colouristic effects.
And we've tried in a very, very microcosmic

948.text:
way to give just some sense to visitors of,
of course, the intrinsic relationship between

953.text:
painting and materials in a juxtaposition
of two  three objects I thought probably

960.text:
one might not think of doing but it actually
works very well, of Elisabeth Vigée Lebrun's

964.text:
self-portrait, which we show on the screen
here, where she presents herself as if she

969.text:
is painting outside en plein air wearing this
straw hat which itself is a reference to a

975.text:
great portrait by Rubens also in our collection.
But in the most perfectly, you know, controlled

981.text:
form; all her colours are laid out on her
palette in proper order. She looks as if she

987.text:
never got any mess on her dress when she painted.
And then you have the absolutely diametrically

992.text:
opposed example of the reality of Turner's
Chelsea palette; a palette found in his Chelsea

998.text:
studio when he died and one of his paint boxes,
a medicine box which was repurposed for the

1006.text:
purpose of storing his pigments. And Turner's
fascinating because he's really at the cusp

1011.text:
of this development of technology in this
box, there is some paint, there are some bladders

1016.text:
filled with paint and then there are also
some bottles as well.

1020.text:
Exactly. Your making the point about Elisabeth
Vigée Lebrun made me think just now what

1027.text:
new materials she might have had available
to her. And, in fact, looking at this self-portrait,

1032.text:
it strikes me there's only one new pigment
at that period that appears before this picture

1039.text:
was painted. And that's a new blue called
Prussian blue which was invented at the beginning

1045.text:
of the 18th Century. And I assume, but I don't
know, that the sky in this picture must be

1051.text:
Prussian blue. It has the look of Prussian
blue. I was also sorry, go on.

1055.text:
Go on, no.
Thinking about Turner, many of you will know

1059.text:
that there's a film about Turner's life about
to appear, I think in the autumn. And so we

1066.text:
are very sorry that it hasn't appeared now
so many, many people would come to see his

1071.text:
palette and his colour box.
But I think we're having an event in early

1075.text:
September when two of the people who've been
involved in fact I know we are  two

1079.text:
of the people who've been very much involved
in the making of the film are going to come

1082.text:
and talk about that. And Joyce Townsend from
Tate is also going to talk later in the summer

1087.text:
about Turner's materials so we will have some
link to it. But it was very good that Ashok

1094.text:
mentioned Prussian blue because the rest of
the exhibition from this introductory room

1098.text:
looks at the colours, though as Ashok said,
we haven't really, we haven't treated white

1105.text:
or black and we are also looking at some,
two colours which are not strictly colours

1109.text:
but are important to how we think about Western
painting colouristically and that's gold and

1115.text:
silver.
But that would be to jump ahead. But our exploration

1119.text:
of blue starts from the extraordinary stone,
the mineral, the semi-precious stone, lapis

1127.text:
lazuli which as you probably know was mined
from one single source in Afghanistan and

1133.text:
then used, brought to Europe along various
trade routes and used particularly in painting

1141.text:
to give a sense of celestial quality. It's
often used, not exclusively of course, for

1146.text:
the robe of the Virgin Mary. And in these
paintings such as the Giovanni da Milano and

1151.text:
the Sassoferrato on the screen there seems
to be some connection between the intense

1156.text:
blue of this that this mineral produces in
pigment form and also the meaning of these

1164.text:
paintings, of these devotional works.
I think one thing that's very interesting

1169.text:
about the images you've chosen is that unusually
for a mineral pigment or indeed any source

1175.text:
of a pigment, the colour of the mineral, the
colour of the pigment particles that you see

1181.text:
under the microscope and paint on the picture,
they're all very, very consistent. It's exactly

1187.text:
the same colours you see in the mineral. Where
very often when some natural material is used

1194.text:
to generate a pigment, the actual colour you
get isn't quite as wonderful as in this case.

1199.text:
But this is a unique material and it's a unique
colour and I think that was celebrated. That

1204.text:
was always celebrated.
And, absolutely, but it might be interesting

1210.text:
to look at azurite which is another blue mineral
which is used more, though not exclusively

1217.text:
at all, in northern Europe than in the south
of Europe. This is Altdorfer's great painting

1222.text:
from the collection of Christ leaving his
mother. Because azurite is, of course, a slightly

1229.text:
in paint it has an almost green-bluish effect,
but that's not quite the colour of the mineral

1234.text:
is it?
No, not at all. No. By the time you grind

1237.text:
the mineral and mix it with medium there's
one effect, particularly with oil that the

1244.text:
mineral is a copper-containing ore and it's
chemically quite active and so it tends to

1251.text:
react chemically with paint medium and that
tends to shift the colour of the paint. And

1256.text:
that's one of the things that goes on so it
either darkens in some cases or it becomes

1261.text:
greener than perhaps the artist intended.
So it doesn't have that stability that ultramarine

1269.text:
When it's used in and ultramarine is stable
whether it's used in either a tempera or in

1276.text:
Unlike some other pigments. No, it's one of,
it's very interesting to see how painters

1282.text:
in the past, possibly more than today were
so sensitive to the question of their materials

1288.text:
and how their materials reacted when mixed
with a particular binding medium. It's something

1295.text:
which you had to think much more of, I suspect,
when it was more difficult for you to actually

1300.text:
get your pigments and your materials of paint.
And since there are so many things I want,

1305.text:
we want to talk about I thought I might just
skip through very quickly into green which

1312.text:
is the next room. And we've tried to organise
each room really round a, sort of, theme.

1318.text:
And one of the themes of green is that you
have to think of your medium, the question

1322.text:
we've just been discussing, but also the relationship
between the development of landscape painting

1328.text:
and the and green pigments. Because painters
had to mix their pigments really in the earlier

1336.text:
period, they had to mix their yellow and their
blue together to get green and sometimes that

1340.text:
leads to rather unstable results.
Although it's not an unstable result in the

1344.text:
painting we're looking at here, the Pollaiuolo,
but that has darkened because of a material

1350.text:
that the painter used, a resin he added and
that has the effect that here, the green of

1357.text:
the landscape here and also of the tree has
become a rather more murky brown, completely

1362.text:
unintentionally.
I suppose there's a point about landscape

1367.text:
painting and colour in general that if you
are painting landscapes you have a need for

1373.text:
a greater range of greens than any other colour
for in a different context. If you want

1379.text:
to represent a green drapery, well, you might
be guided by the pigment that you have available

1384.text:
but if you have to represent nature you need
to be accurate in that sort of way, so, you

1389.text:
need a great range of colour. And so, hence
a lot of mixed pigment.

1393.text:
And a lot of thought. And then, of course,
the discovery of new pigments in the 19th

1397.text:
Century was a complete godsend to painters,
wasn't it?

1400.text:
It was, yes, particularly amongst the greens,
I think, as you say.

1404.text:
Yes. And these two pictures which we're showing
in the show, a great two landscapes of

1409.text:
very similar sizes actually, and rather interesting
as a pair together, Philippe Rousseau's mountainous,

1415.text:
sort of, valley of 1860 and Cezanne's Hillside
in Provence of about 30 years later. And these

1422.text:
sorts of effects were only really possible
with the new range of green pigments which

1426.text:
were available to painters. And they were
also stable too, or more so than previous

1431.text:
ones.
Yes, absolutely, yes. But I suppose in a way

1433.text:
the Philippe Rousseau has a slightly different
intent in terms of the intensity of the colour

1438.text:
that he proposes for his landscape which is
a much more, sort of, traditionally naturalistic,

1446.text:
kind of, depiction. In fact both landscapes
contain a 19th Century invention called viridian

1453.text:
which is a very strong, deep green colour.
But in the Rousseau it's there in mixed paint

1460.text:
and so its, sort of, particular colour quality
is a bit submerged. Whereas in the Cezanne

1464.text:
it, sort of, sings out at you.
Yes. Is it?

1469.text:
It's in the dark green, exactly where you
are. And then there's another pigment called

1473.text:
emerald green which is the middle distance,
very intense rather light yellowish green.

1479.text:
Exactly. So, that's another 19th Century material.
But I think, Ashok, you wanted to say something

1487.text:
about one mineral source which we don't�
which we're not including in the exhibition

1491.text:
which was very important for greens and that's
malachite.

1494.text:
Exactly. The reason we didn't include malachite
as an example of a traditional green pigment

1500.text:
is it's quite difficult to find very clear
examples of its use in our collection. And

1506.text:
yet it's quite an important pigment traditionally,
rather more for wall painting and fresco than

1513.text:
it is for easel painting. It happens we have
in the collection a series of detached frescoes

1519.text:
by Domenichino and they show landscapes in
which there's a great deal of malachite. It's

1526.text:
really the only green pigment. They were rather
too large to take

1531.text:
Put downstairs.
Exactly. But the images you see, just to show

1537.text:
you what malachite looks like in its, sort
of, massive mineral form, this enormous vase

1542.text:
is called the Demidoff Vase, it's in the Metropolitan
Museum of Art in New York, and it shows a

1550.text:
particular, rather deep, intense green colour
of mineral malachite which you would think

1555.text:
would make it a very good pigment for all
kinds of painting. But it happens that when

1563.text:
you grind it up it doesn't have a very intense
colour and that's particularly the case when

1570.text:
it's mixed with a paint medium like oil. It
works quite well in egg tempera, as all pigments

1578.text:
which don't have pigments show their intrinsic
colour rather better in the egg tempera than

1584.text:
they do in oil, generally speaking.
But the image you see here; this is malachite

1594.text:
which is ground to different levels of fineness.
So this is very coarse, this is, sort of,

1599.text:
medium coarse and this is fine. And what this
shows is, the more you grind it up, the less

1604.text:
powerful the colour becomes because the pigment
particles scatter a lot of white light instead

1610.text:
of just green light. And so you need to, in
order to make a workable paint, grind the

1618.text:
pigment quite finely. So that makes it less
suitable for easel painting than you find
